the production of chemicals and petrochemicals - energy use and any emissions in the processes
Anything without iron in it - biggest are aluminium, copper, lead, nickel, tin, titanium and zinc, and alloys such as brass. Also precious metals and rare-earth metals.
life-cycle of paper production, converting or printing and distribution, and then disposal at the end of its lifetime.
Digital industries, media, telecoms, all fit in here, but so do things like financial services, hospitality, defence, anything that's not mentioned above.

Land use changes. Cutting down trees for farmland/grazing land.
Methane is a big part, but also CO2 from transportation and feeding them, and general energy use.
yep! Also things like grow lamps and heating/ventilating greenhouses etc.
Emissions from sewage treatment plants (and open sewers in the developing world)

This is the footprint of the energy that's required to produce energy, if that makes sense? Energy use in power-producing processes. Light/ventilation in power plants, transmission losses (which are big).
Footprint of energy used to dig coal out of the ground.
